docs.lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Texas Pacific Group are proposing putting $600 million of badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans, a person close to the negotiations said yesterday. Under the deal, which could be completed as soon as next week, the two buyout firms would provide $300 million in equity financing and raise an additional $300 million in debt for Oxford, the troubled managed care company. Though the details are being worked out, the firms could end up with 15 percent to 20 percent of the company, the person said.

headline.main: $600 Million Infusion Seen In Oxford Deal

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Cuba Says It Will Free 200 Political Prisoners The Cuban Government said that it would free more than 200 prisoners held on political and other charges. Vatican officials described the announcement as a response to Pope John Paul II's appeal last month for the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest life insurer, dangled the prospect of a windfall to its policyholders under a plan announced yesterday to set up a new corporate structure. The company says as much as $12 billion is at stake, or about $1,100 on average per policyholder. But the windfall may not be all it seems. The pie, which reflects years of accumulated profits, may not be distributed entirely in cash, and critics worry that the change the company is contemplating may also end up costing policyholders more in premiums. [Page D1.]

headline.main: A $12 Billion Carrot for Prudential Policyholders

docs.abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America, nation's largest life insurer, dangles prospect of windfall to its policyholders under plan announced to set up new corporate structure; company says as much as $12 billion is at stake, or about $1,100 on average per policyholder; pie, which reflects years of accumulated profit, may not be distributed entirely in cash, and critics worry that change company is contemplating may also end up costing policyholders more in premiums; company, which is still suffering after effects of series of scandals, stands to benefit; it proposes to shift from mutual ownership, in which policyholders nominally own company, to regular publicly traded company; policyholders would become shareholders and company would gain access to bounty of stock market, while enabling top managers to eventually collect potentially lucrative stock options in addition to their salaries; charts show Prudential's business; table of biggest life insurers (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The decision by a Federal judge here to strike down the President's line item veto power today did more than address a thorny constitutional question. It preserved, for the moment, a set of New York State hospital taxes that are crucial to financing health care services for the poor and uninsured. For that reason, hospital industry officials and a host of state officials. including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, joined in praising the ruling, which is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

headline.main: Veto Ruling Spares New York Health Financing

docs.abstract: Decision by a Federal judge to strike down President's line item veto power does more than address thorny constitutional question; it preserves, for the moment, a set of New York State hospital taxes that are crucial to financing health car services for the poor and uninsured; for that reason, hospital industry officials and host of city and state officials, including New York City Mayor Giuliani, join in praising ruling, which is likely to be appealed to Supreme Court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Politics has never been a cheap sport in California, home to a dozen media markets stretching over a span equal to the distance from New Jersey to Georgia and to a diffuse and desultory political culture where paid television commercials are king. But as the 1998 gubernatorial race begins here in earnest this month, the state of so many firsts seems poised to set yet another record, for the most expensive state election campaign in American history. And in no small measure that is the work of one man, a demibillionaire Democratic businessman named Al Checchi (pronounced CHECK-ee), who is running for office for the first time.

headline.main: California Governor's Race: A New Height in Spending

docs.abstract: 1998 gubernatorial race in California appears poised to set record as most expensive state election campaign in American history; much of spending comes from demibillionaire Alfred A Checchi, 49-year-old investor who has come from nowhere to virtually dominate Democratic field at moment; Sen Dianne Feinstein, whose husband is onetime partner of Checchi and himself a millionaire, chose not to run for governor last month--though she led in all polls--because she confessed dreading prospect that Checchi would spend millions of dollars attacking her in primary; Leon E Panetta, former Congressman who served as Pres Clinton's chief of staff, concluded last week that he could not possibly raise enough money to compete; Lt Gov Gray Davis, who has spent years planning a gubernatorial bid and amassing war chest of more than $4 million, now finds Checchi nipping at his heels in public opinion polls; only other Democrat who decided she could afford to join fray is Repr Jane Harman, who represents coastal district on south edges of Los Angeles and whose husband has fortune akin to Checchi's; on Republican side, conservative State Atty Gen, Dan Lungren, faces only token opposition; Checchi photo (M)
docs.snippet: Politics has never been a cheap sport in California, home to a dozen media markets stretching over a span equal to the distance from New Jersey to Georgia and to a diffuse and desultory political culture where paid television commercials are king.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Charlie Norwood, a small-town dentist with an oversized dislike of big government, plunged into politics in 1994 in large part to fight President Clinton's plans for national health insurance. But three years later this feisty, good-natured conservative finds himself at the center of one of of this year's fiercest, and oddest, political storms, one that has placed him squarely in cahoots with his old nemesis, Mr. Clinton, divided his own Republican political ''family,'' as he calls it, and infuriated the party's leadership. Mr. Norwood is pushing for more government regulation of the managed-care industry.

headline.main: A Conservative Battles Corporate Health Care

docs.abstract: Rep Charlie Norwood, conservative dentist who ran for office in part to fight Pres Clinton's plans for national health insurance, is pushing for more government regulation of managed-care industry; is joined by Clinton Administration and liberals like Sen Edward M Kennedy, unusual coalition that shows depth of backlash against managed care; he comments, interview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of people without medical insurance is rising far faster in New York State than in the rest of the country, a jump that has left nearly one in five New Yorkers under age 65 uninsured, several new studies show. The increase has come despite a robust economy that has created hundreds of thousands of new jobs in the region. In fact, the new data suggest a dark side to New York's economic resurgence: many of the new jobs are in small, low-wage service or retail businesses, which because of the high cost have become less and less likely to offer their workers health benefits.

headline.main: Even as Economy Booms, More People Are Going Without Insurance

docs.abstract: Number of people without medical insurance is rising far faster in New York State than in rest of country, jump that has left nearly one in five New Yorkers under age 65 uninsured; increase has come despite robust economy that has created hundreds of thousands of new jobs in region; many of new jobs are in small, low-wage businesses, which are less likely to offer their workers health benefits; one-third of uninsured in New York are legal or illegal immigrants, who are more likely to take low-paying jobs; United Hospital Fund says about 2.2 million New Yorkers under age 65, or 13.9 percent, were uninsured in 1991; says in 1996, number had risen to 3.1 million, or 19.1 percent; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lisa Holloway spends hours every day honing homemade karate techniques in her bedroom, but she has yet to defeat her greatest foe: schizophrenia. In 1984, when Lisa was 19, the onset of mental illness transformed her from a pleasant teen-ager whose feet were constantly tucked inside a pair of roller skates to a terrified woman whose legs dangled from a window as she contemplated suicide.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Fighting Schizophrenia In the Throes of Poverty

docs.abstract: Article on how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped Ann Holloway, Bronx woman whose 32-year-old daughter, Lisa, is schizophrenic; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After four years of cutting taxes and state spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reversed course today with a proposed $17.9 billion budget that recommends nearly $1 billion in new spending for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and a handful of other programs. Mrs. Whitman would pay for the largest budget increase since she took office with extra tax revenue flowing from the economic boom. State officials expect to end the current fiscal year, on June 30, with a $1 billion surplus and an additional $710 million in new revenue for the new fiscal year.

headline.main: Whitman Shifts Course to Propose Hefty Increase for New Spending

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman, after four years of cutting taxes and state spending, reverses course with proposed $17.9 billion budget that recommends nearly $1 billion in new spending for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and handful of other programs; Whitman would pay for largest budget increase since she took office with extra tax revenue flowing from economic boom; says she wants to put $650 million into 'rainy day' fund; proposes eliminating sales tax on long-distance calls made within state, saving consumers and businesses about $24 million a year; calls for constitutional amendment to make it tougher for future lawmakers to raise taxes and says she wants to allow motorists to renew their driver's licenses once a decade; photo of Whitman with former Gov Thomas H Kean (M)
